sentence.content: The epidemic of bovine spongiform encephalopathy or &apost;mad cow&apost; disease - which has killed more than 100,000 animals in the UK - is causing a new wave of public concern.

sentence.content: The advisers, led by the government&apost;s chief medical officer Kenneth Calman and chief veterinary officer Keith Meldrum, put out a detailed statement to justify their view that last month&apost;s death of 65-year-old Duncan Templeman - following that of Peter Warhurst, 61, a year ago - showed &apost;no features that give cause for undue concern&apost;.

sentence.content: Robert Will of Edinburgh&apost;s Western General Hospital, who has been monitoring CJD in the UK since 1990 on behalf of the health department, calculated that there was only a five per cent probability of even a single case occurring by chance among dairy farmers with BSE-affected herds.

sentence.content: One argument put forward by the health department is that CJD has such a long incubation period - typically 10 to 20 years - that clinical symptoms would not yet have appeared, even if BSE had triggered any cases of CJD.

sentence.content: The second annual report of Will&apost;s National CJD Surveillance Unit in Edinburgh, published last month, shows what looks at first sight like a disturbing rise in incidence: from 32 UK cases in the year ended April 1991 to 37 in 1991/92 and 46 in 1992/3.

sentence.content: The epidemic continues to defy the ministry of agriculture&apost;s predictions that it is about to wane; so far this year there have been 26,695 reported cases, compared with 25,898 to the same date last year.

sentence.content: Veterinary experts say that almost all of the 102,000 confirmed BSE cases so far can be attributed to scrapie-contaminated feed.

sentence.content: According to their investigations, maternal transmission from cow to calf - which would prolong the epidemic - is very rare or non-existent.

sentence.content: Scientists trying to understand the epidemic face an unusual problem: BSE, scrapie and CJD are caused by a bizarre, infectious agent, the prion, which does not follow the normal rules of microbiology.

sentence.content: Recent research shows that the prion is an abnormal form of a protein that is normally present in the brain (though its normal function is not yet known).

sentence.content: Once in place in the victim&apost;s brain, it catalyses what John Collinge, a prion researcher at St Mary&apost;s Hospital Medical School, London, called a slow &apost;chemical chain reaction&apost;, converting the normal protein into its own abnormal form.
